author: schone_wizard
content: i just noticed this flag ``--eth1_withdrawal_address`` on the eth2 deposit cli tool.  originally i dont believe this existed when we launched.  what does this option add exactly and what happens to those who didn't use this option when the deposit cli didn't have it

author: carlbeek
content: Basically it allows you to directly target your eventual withdrawal at an ethereum address as opposed to having to specify an address later. It's primarily designed for staking service providers who want to withdraw to a contract. The vast majority of private stakers have not been using this setting and so will have a slightly different withdrawal experience, from those that did. It's not better or worse, just different functionality for those who need it. Read more here: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2149

author: potuz
content: re is not better or worse: nothing is set in stone, but I'd bet it's "worse" (for private stakers) to have an eth1 prefix in the sense that it's higher entropy, whatever withdrawal method is approved, surely BLS addresses will be able to either withdraw to an ETH1 address and/or switch to an ETH1 prefix.  The other way seems out of the question

author: potuz
content: Going from the linked message (about an API call allowing multiple validators requesting blocks) to a one time change of credentials is a big leap...
